Award.AwardTitle: Hydrocarbon and Alkene Conversion Chemistry with PFAP Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program supports the research of Professor Dean M. Roddick of the University of Wyoming on the development of perfluoroalkylated phosphine (PFAP) metal complex catalysts for the efficient conversion of simple hydrocarbon feedstocks to useful products. Specific challenges for investigation are the selective dehydrogenation of alkanes and tandem oxidation of alkanes to alcohols and ketones, as well as the controlled oligomerization of fluoroolefins. A key feature of PFAP systems is their unique air- and moisture-stability, which allows metal reaction centers to carry out fundamental C-H and C-C bond forming steps under stringent oxidative and hydrolytic conditions. Density Functional Theory (DFT) studies further suggest that group 10 metal PFAP systems are particularly well-suited to novel fluoroolefin oligomerization and polymerization chemistry.

This award will provide a twofold impact on the larger community. First, this research project addresses several critically important and unrealized research challenges in catalysis. Discovery of practical and efficient conversion methodologies from abundant hydrocarbon feedstocks to useful chemical precursors and feedstocks would transform chemical industry, improve atom economy and increase synthetic efficiencies. Second, Professor Roddick's research group trains not only graduate and undergraduate students as future professionals in catalysis research, but also spearheads outreach to community colleges throughout Wyoming through visits and workshops, and also collaborates and contributes to the newly-formed School of Energy Resources at the University of Wyoming.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary area of our research concerns the development of new fluorinated molecular catalysts for hydrocarbon conversion chemistry.  Following our initial discovery of highly active iridium and ruthenium catalysts with unprecedented air and moisture stability, we have begun to address catalyst stability and activity limitations by the design of new protected systems; initial surveys of catalyst activity confirms our working hypothesis that engineering steric protection results in higher activity and stability.  A related research emphasis is the development of hybrid catalyst systems based on a mixed alkyl/fluoroalkyl ligand environment. Optimization of these catalyst systems will have a significant impact on the future utilization of fossil hydrocarbon resources. 

 

Olefin oligomerization chemistry dominates the worldwide production of polymers, surfactants, linear aldehydes and alcohols, etc. One of the key (and largely unrealized) future challenges is to extend this chemistry to functionalized alkenes; to this end, most recent Group 10 catalyst development has almost exclusively focused on nickel and palladium systems with nitrogen and oxygen-based ligand sets. Our report of a highly active platinum ethylene dimerization catalyst provides an important starting point for the development of new alkene oligomerization phosphine-based catalysts. As part of this work, we have discovered a novel synthetic route to the formation of highly labile platinum arene complexes using arenium acids in a fluoroarene solvent medium. The general strategy of accessing highly reactive unsaturated cationic intermediates through the use of the arenium acids will be exploited in further studies of cationic alkene and perfluoroalkene complexes.


Last Modified: 01/31/2016
Modified by: Dean M Roddick

A related research emphasis is the development of hybrid catalyst systems based on a mixed alkyl/fluoroalkyl ligand environment. Optimization of these catalyst systems will have a significant impact on the future utilization of fossil hydrocarbon resources.
